metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Argentina, a work of history and social description published in 1910 by W. A. Hirst, an American writer.
main_question:
It has been pointed out that the blockade of 1902 was not originally instituted on account of Venezuela's failure to pay debts, but to obtain redress for outrages inflicted upon the subjects of the blockading Powers, that Venezuela had refused the suggestion of arbitration, that Dr. Drago misunderstood the Venezuelan question, and that the Powers never intended permanently to occupy any part of Venezuela. Further, Mr. Hay, in his reply to Dr. 

Drago, said: "The President declared in his Message to

Congress, December 3, 1901, that by the Munroe Doctrine 'we do not guarantee any State against punishment if it misconducts itself, [masked clause describing a condition or proviso] Although the practice, against which the Drago Doctrine protests is liable to be abused, it would hardly be prudent on the part of European Powers nor conducive to progress in backward States, if the right of collecting debts were sur- 

See the Annual Register of 1907, p. 345.

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause describing a condition or proviso]:
source_genre: work of history and social description
answer_strings: provided that punishment does not take the form of the acquisition of territory by any non-American Power.'"
provided that punishment involves the acquisition of territory by some non-American power
unless they can count beforehand on a good chance of immediate employment
if the right of collecting debts were sur- See the Annual Register of 1907
unless such misconduct involves an attack on their citizens and property
provided that the state has failed to observe its treaty obligations or has engaged in conduct contrary to the principles of international law
passage:
Further, Mr. Hay, in his reply to Dr. 

Drago, said: "The President declared in his Message to

Congress, December 3, 1901, that by the Munroe Doctrine 'we do not guarantee any State against punishment if it misconducts itself, provided that punishment does not take the form of the acquisition of territory by any non-American Power.'"

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Argentina, a work of history and social description published in 1910 by W. A. Hirst, an American writer.
main_question:
France makes steady progress, and Italy shows a large increase, as is only to be expected, because the emigration from Italy has long been very large. It may be added that 

French goods make their way by sheer merit, for France has in her own land ample scope for her scanty population. Some advantage may be obtained by her as the head of the Latin race, [masked clause revising an implied expectation]. It is very interesting to see how Argentina has passed from small to great things in matters of trade.

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause revising an implied expectation]:
source_genre: work of history and social description
answer_strings: but wherever there are women and luxury there will French trade flourish, and further, in machinery of many kinds France, if equalled by any other nation for excellence, is equalled by England alone

but wherever there are scarcity and simplicity, French trade will wither, and further, in machinery of many kinds, France, if surpassed by any other nation for excellence, is surpassed by England alone
but it is a peculiarity about Argentina that the people hurry to institute a great export trade long before they think of supplying themselves adequately with an article
but the third view is naturally that of Argentina, which is every year receiving an abundant stream of white colonists to develop the industries which cry aloud for labour
but her influence is tempered by the fierce competition from other nations within Latin America.
even as its resources are comparatively scarce
passage: Some advantage may be obtained by her as the head of the Latin race, but wherever there are women and luxury there will French trade flourish, and further, in machinery of many kinds France, if equalled by any other nation for excellence, is equalled by England alone.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Argentina, a work of history and social description published in 1910 by W. A. Hirst, an American writer.
main_question:
The Spaniards still appear to have had a design to check the Portuguese in 94
Brazil, but Cabot evidently found them too strong in that quarter, so, says Purchas, "he thought good to busy himself in something that might be profitable; and entered the year 29 discovering the River of Plate, where he was almost three years; and not being seconded, with relation of that which he had found, returned to Castile, having gone many leagues up the River. He found plate or silver among the Indians of those countries, [masked clause describing a cause or reason] Here Purchas makes two mistakes.

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause describing a cause or reason]:
source_genre: work of history and social description
answer_strings: for in the wars which these Indians had with those of the kingdoms of Peru they took it, and from it is called the River of Plate, of which the country hath taken the name."
for in the wars which these Indians had with those of the kingdoms of Peru they failed to find silver, and the lack of plate hath given the river its name."
for experience showed them the immense resources of their country, and proved that it could subsist upon its revenues without asking for anything from Peru or Spain (Arcos' ""La Plata," p. 241)
for the Portuguese claimed indefinite territory in this direction under the convention of Tordesillas, and it behoved Spain to assert ownership before it was too late
because he was looking to gain support and resources from his king.
as a result of the Indians having discovered rich silver deposits in the region."
passage: He found plate or silver among the Indians of those countries, for in the wars which these Indians had with those of the kingdoms of Peru they took it, and from it is called the River of Plate, of which the country hath taken the name."

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Argentina, a work of history and social description published in 1910 by W. A. Hirst, an American writer.
main_question:
Beyond a doubt, in

Spanish America there is an unexampled field for a devout missionary; the foe is merely apathy, and if a warmer spirit were breathed into the Church in Argentina, and if the clergy paid more attention to the intellectual side of their calling, the results would be remarkable. [masked sentence describing a tension or contrast] Statistically, there can be no doubt that Argentina belongs unreservedly to Rome; only the merest fraction, perhaps forty thousand, of the population is outside that Church.

Write a sentence appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked sentence describing a tension or contrast]:
source_genre: work of history and social description
answer_strings: But if the religious indifference spreads downwards, Argentina, like France, may see her population dwindle, and her army decay, and may be prevented from taking a high position among world Powers.
But if the religious fervor spreads upwards, Argentina, like France, may see her population swell, and her army strengthen, and may be encouraged to take a high position among world Powers.

However, it must be remembered that the fraternal spirit of the Greeks did not preserve them from internecine wars, and Argentina, flanked by each of the other two powerful South American Republics, cannot afford to neglect her armaments.
There is, however, little doubt that Argentina possesses a good army, sufficient for the defence of even her very vulnerable frontier.
Yet, despite the numerical dominance of Catholicism, there exists a profound disconnection between the church and the people's hearts.

Yet the same apathy that hampers missionary zeal is evident in the clergy’s neglect of the nation’s material hardships, underscoring a stark tension between spiritual devotion and social responsibility.
passage: But if the religious indifference spreads downwards, Argentina, like France, may see her population dwindle, and her army decay, and may be prevented from taking a high position among world Powers.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Argentina, a work of history and social description published in 1910 by W. A. Hirst, an American writer.
main_question:
He also attempted to settle the country, but without success, for Thomas 

Cavendish (who named Port Desire after his own ship) saw in 1586, twenty-three famished Spaniards, the only survivors of the city of King Philip, founded by Gamboa on the Straits. These poor creatures were trying to return to the Plate district. [masked sentence describing an inference or effect] In 1590 John Davys found a solitary straggler here, and the bold navigator thus describes his barren experiences: "Here we made a boat of the boards of our chests, which, being finished, we sent seven armed men in the same on land on the north shore, being wafted on land by the savages with certain white skins; who, as soon as they came on shore, were presently killed by an hundred of the wild people in the sight of two of our men, which rowed them on shore, which two only escaped back again to us with the boat.

Write a sentence appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked sentence describing an inference or effect]:
source_genre: work of history and social description
answer_strings: Cavendish, therefore, named the deserted settlement the Town of Famine, and it retains the name of Port Famine to this day."
Cavendish, therefore, named the flourishing settlement the City of Plenty, and it retains the name of Port Plenty to this day
Thus, because the land in question contained a number of different tribes, they received by analogy the name Chacu, which the Spaniards have corrupted into Chaco."
This grim discovery underscored the futility of earlier attempts at colonization and the harsh realities of survival in this unforgiving land.
Their return was fraught with danger, as hostile natives constantly threatened their passage.
passage: Cavendish, therefore, named the deserted settlement the Town of Famine, and it retains the name of Port Famine to this day."

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Argentina, a work of history and social description published in 1910 by W. A. Hirst, an American writer.
main_question:
About twenty years later another traveller estimates the population at fifteen thousand and says: "The city presents an extremely clean and orderly appearance; the streets, which intersect at right angles, are well kept and well lighted. The only manufacture in the place is that of leather. There is no newspaper, although formerly there were two weekly journals published. . . . The climate is very salubrious, [masked clause conceding a limit or exception]. There are no foreigners in the town, nor even in the province, except a few French and two or three English: the government architect is a Frenchman, who possesses both wealth and influence."

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause conceding a limit or exception]:
source_genre: work of history and social description
answer_strings: though the rain does not fall in sufficient quantity
although rain is continuous and abundant
though perhaps the best they can obtain."
except during certain times of the year when winds bring dust from the neighboring plains
except for the brief, oppressive heat that grips the town in midsummer
passage: The climate is very salubrious, though the rain does not fall in sufficient quantity.

metadata_frame: The following passage comes from Argentina, a work of history and social description published in 1910 by W. A. Hirst, an American writer.
main_question:
There is, in fact, little interest in any such matters on the part of the population, and the President is now lamenting the disinclination to a sea-faring life, and of recent years steps have been taken to obtain more satisfactory results; but the total mercantile marine, as yet, amounts to barely 100,000 tons. There is, however, a College for training officers, and also engineers and stokers for the mercantile marine, and there is a Pilot School, and various measures show that the authorities are alive to the importance of the question. In his last Message to Congress the President said: "One of the principal reasons for granting privileges to ships flying the Argentine flag is the employment of native crews, [masked clause describing an inference or effect] The Argentine sailor is a land-conscript, laboriously taught an unfamiliar art, which he learns wonderfully well.

Write a clause appropriate for this book that could stand in the position marked by [masked clause describing an inference or effect]:
source_genre: work of history and social description
answer_strings: so that the nation's sons may find a new path of life, and the navy a fresh source from which to draw sailors in case of an emergency."
so that the nation's sons remain on their old paths, and the navy is left with no new recruits when emergencies arise

so that it is very easy to find one's way about, for if a pedestrian desires a cross street, say to the north, he has only to march northwards up any given street and he must eventually reach his designation

so that eventually the Argentine flocks were as sorely in need of new blood as were those of France, Germany, or Russia, which, until the middle of the eighteenth century, had never had the benefit of a cross with the old Spanish strain
and thus fostering a sense of national pride and economic independence."
which secures a reliable workforce for the nation's merchant fleet."
passage: In his last Message to Congress the President said: "One of the principal reasons for granting privileges to ships flying the Argentine flag is the employment of native crews, so that the nation's sons may find a new path of life, and the navy a fresh source from which to draw sailors in case of an emergency."
